## Question 2
```{r}
#Generate 2 lists of random values with different standard deviations
valuesA <- rnorm(10000, mean=0, sd=0.2)
valuesB <- rnorm(10000, mean=0, sd=0.5)

#Display the lists in histograms (The code is not echoed, but it is the same as in the assignment)
```

```{r echo=FALSE}
hist(valuesA, xlim=c(-5,5))
hist(valuesB, xlim=c(-5,5))
```

#When sigma is 0.2 the values are more concentrated around the mean and the frequency at the mean is higher. When sigma is 0.5 the values are spread between -2 and 2 and the average frequency is much lower. This difference is because the standard deviation represents how spread out the values are from the mean and a higher standard deviation leads to a more spread  histogram.

## Question 3 (a-e)
```{r echo=FALSE}
library(ggplot2)

dat <- data.frame(cond=factor(rep(c("A", "B"), each=200)), rating=c(rnorm(200), rnorm(200, mean=0.8)))

# Overlaid histograms
ggplot(dat, aes(x=rating, fill=cond)) +
geom_histogram(binwidth=.5, alpha=.5, position="identity")

# Interleaved histograms
ggplot(dat, aes(x=rating, fill=cond)) + geom_histogram(binwidth=.5, position="dodge")

# Density plots
ggplot(dat, aes(x=rating, colour=cond)) + geom_density()

# Density plots with semitransparent fill
ggplot(dat, aes(x=rating, fill=cond)) + geom_density(alpha=.3)
```

#Question 3f
```{r}
library(ggplot2)
diabetes <- read.csv("diabetes_train.csv")

#Overlaid Histograms
ggplot(diabetes, aes(x=mass, fill=class)) + geom_histogram(binwidth=.5, alpha=.5, position="identity")

#Interleaved Histograms
ggplot(diabetes, aes(x=mass, fill=class)) + geom_histogram(binwidth=.5, position="dodge")

#Density Plots
ggplot(diabetes,aes(x=mass, colour=class)) + geom_density()

#Density Plots with Semi-Transparent Fill
ggplot(diabetes,aes(x=mass, fill=class)) + geom_density(alpha=0.3)
```

#Question 4
```{r}
library(tidyr)
library(dplyr)
passengers <-read.csv("titanic.csv", header=TRUE)

#Drop rows containing empty values then display the summary of the resulting data frame
passengers %>% drop_na() %>% summary()

#Display all of the male passengers by passing the dataframe into the filter function
passengers %>% filter(Sex=="male")

#Display the passengers in descending order based on their fare.
passengers %>% arrange(desc(Fare))

#Create a new column (FamSize) in the passengers data frame based on the parch and sibsp attributes
passengers %>% mutate(FamSize=Parch + SibSp)

#Display the average fare of passengers based on their gender and how many of each gender survived
passengers %>% group_by(Sex) %>% summarise(meanFare = mean(Fare), numSurv=sum(Survived))
```
